ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to read Old English poetry, how to pay better attention to the form as well as content of poetry, and bit about the styles and poetry of a few great poets. I also learned how to be a better writer, and even a little bit about how to pronounce Old English!
I got an introduction to English poetry, and I learned how to read more carefully.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the readings
Weakness: the professor

I thought it was really great for learning to appreciate the poetry we read. Reading it out loud and then slowly discussing selections really allowed us to think about the writing, style, and form. The workload was also not overbearing at all, which gave us time to really focus on the readings. It did sometimes feel like our class discussions never had enough time to cover everything that was important. Also, I felt like we didn't talk enough about form and style when reading Paradise Lost (heavy focus on ideas).

Strengths: fair workload
Weaknesses: not the most dynamic reading list
I only wish that this course could have been longer so that we could spend more time on the Canterbury Tales and the Shakespeare/Donne/Herbert portion of the class!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, even if you don't think you like poetry. I think it is a great way to deepen your interest in and understanding of poetry in a small class with a great professor.
Yes, for an English major requirement OR if you are super passionate about poetry from this time period.
Yes! If you are willing to put the work into the readings and discussions, you will learn a lot and improve your writing.
